Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9136 - Silicon Valley Study Tour","description":"

Over the past few decades Silicon Valley and its startup ecosystem have consistently produced high growth companies that have come to dominate industries worldwide from pioneering companies like HP and Fairchild and technology giants like Apple and Google through to a new generation of disruptors like Uber and AirBnB. This course, which takes place in Silicon Valley, provides you with an opportunity to get deeper insight into the world's most successful startup ecosystem and to identify the lessons that can be learnt for countries and individual companies that are seeking to enhance innovation and foster greater levels of entrepreneurship. During this course you will meet with and gain insights from entrepreneurs, investors, executives and industry experts who are living and working in the Valley and will develop practical insights and a fresh perspective that you will be able to apply to your organisation big or small. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dfc72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619ee","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

At the conclusion of the-study tour students are required to submit an encompassing self-reflection report synthesizing the lessons learned from the whole experience. This report should not be longer than five pages. Although this report needs to use the daily reflection journal for inspiration, it is not supposed to be simply a synthesis of those journal entries. Instead, it needs to discuss explicitly how this whole experience has changed your previous standpoint and/or how you can use this experience to engage in further professional/ personal opportunities.

The appendix to this self-reflection report will be the pages of daily self-reflection journal in which you record your experiences while on the field-study trip. Each of the journal entries should expose how the occurrences and interactions you have experienced that day can be transformed in lessons for your professional practice and/or how these experiences can reveal new insights in terms of the assessment of the investment opportunity being evaluated by your team. It is important to note that these journals need to go deeper than being a mere recount of the events of the day. It needs to interpret the new information and integrate it with past experiences, and specifically, engage with the framework discussed in this class and discuss its personal implications in terms of professional development.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"93c72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"93c72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9bc72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"57c72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"team bios and summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

This is a group assignment and should be completed prior to your departure for the US. This introduction will be provided to the organisations we visit on the field trip, as well as to our Australian ‘live case study’ organisations.  It’s very important that we have this information and that you are able to sell yourself to the people we will meet.

Each member of the group should put together a one-page summary for themselves, preferably including a headshot. You should also have a one-page summary of the team and the skills that you bring to the project. This can take whatever form you like but it should resemble the type of summary that you might find in a proposal for consulting work or the sort of summary you would include in a pitch deck for a startup proposal. You can also take the opportunity to discuss how you will work as a team, set expectations  and identify who will play what roles.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9fc72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67c72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619fe","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Consultants report for company","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a written report to an Australian organisation that is interested in shifting some or all of its operations to Silicon Valley. 

For this course we are using live case studies to act as a vehicle for you to learn through. You will be provided with a brief on the company or have the opportunity to meet with the founder or company representative prior to deparrture to the US or on the first day of the study tour. Once the study tour is over your team should work by itself to write up the final report and recommendations. Having a concrete case study to look at the Silicon Valley ecosystem through will help you get a better understanding of the experience that an entrepreneur of company might have when thinking about moving their business or expanding across geographies.

While feedback from the case study organisation is important, and will be useful to you, it will not determine the final assessment of this task. Rather our focus will be on the extent to which you were able to draw on insights and conversations gained during the study tour, relevant academic and industry sources and your own experience and commercial acumen to provide a clear set of well-considered recommendations. The specific assessment criteria we will use for this written report include the following

1.     Was it clearly presented and did it contain clear recommendations? Was it written in a manner that was useful for company or organisation for which it was prepared?

2.     Given the information you were able to gather did you demonstrate a good understanding of some of the key issues facing the business or industry vertical in which the case study organisation operated?

3.     Did you draw a variety of useful sources including insights gained during the study tour, where appropriate academic frameworks and theories, government reports, industry reports and examples of other business in the same industry or in an adjacent market?

To accompany the written report you are also expected to prepare a short (no more than 5 minute) video pitch that summarises the key findings of the report. You can use any format you like for this element. We will be happy to provide some recommendations during the study tour. From a learning goal perspective it is designed to provide evidence of your team’s oral communication skills but is also something that we can share with the case study organisation. While in Silicon Valley you may consider taking videos and photos that could be included in your video presentation.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"93c72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9bc72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9fc72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ebc72fe5db025490eb6b147a3a9619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This course is based on experiential learning and for you to get the most from the experience it is important that you are present and that you are actively engaged in all. For this reason we have attached a substantial proportion of the assessment to attendance and participation. Throughout the study tour the facilitators will be monitoring your contributions to assess the extent to which you are adding value to the experience of the class as whole. The criteria that we will be using include

1.     Are they physically and mentally present? Are they ready to depart on time? Are they distracted and too often on their phones?

2.     Is the student willing to contribute to the discussion with the class and with the companies and representatives we meet with?

3.     Are they respectful in their engagements? Do they leave opportunities open for others to ask questions? Do they encourage and build on the contributions of others?

4.     Are they attempting to contribute to the understanding of the group as a whole or do they often just focus on narrow issues of their own interest?

5.     Are they good ambassadors of the group and AGSM? Do they express appreciation to the people the people that we meet? Are they behaving in a manner that will pave future opportunities for AGSM students in the region.

A couple of other points:

Success for us in the course is if we are in position to allocate high grades for this element to all participants in the program. If for some reason you are not meeting the standards we expect we will let you know during the study tour so you have an opportunity to recalibrate.To create opportunities for everyone to contribute to the learning experience of the class the facilitators will nominate particular groups to start and lead debriefs and discussion after company visits. This will be done on the ground during the study tour.

contentlets.description: Over the past few decades Silicon Valley and its startup ecosystem have consistently produced high growth companies that have come to dominate industries worldwide from pioneering companies like HP and Fairchild and technology giants like Apple and Google through to a new generation of disruptors like Uber and AirBnB. This course, which takes place in Silicon Valley, provides you with an opportunity to get deeper insight into the world's most successful startup ecosystem and to identify the lessons that can be learnt for countries and individual companies that are seeking to enhance innovation and foster greater levels of entrepreneurship. During this course you will meet with and gain insights from entrepreneurs, investors, executives and industry experts who are living and working in the Valley and will develop practical insights and a fresh perspective that you will be able to apply to your organisation big or small.
contentlets.title: Silicon Valley Study Tour

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9137","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9137 - Advanced Finance","description":"

This course focuses on advanced financial decisions of corporate managers. First, the course expands on the traditional project evaluation criteria by introducing real options and valuation techniques in the presence of uncertainly. Second, it explains the nuances associated with various forms of debt finance. Third, it explains how to hedge a company's cash flows and balance sheet from both domestic and international exposures. The course uses case studies to illustrate the application of theoretical concepts to real-life.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f8361bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment includes a series of weekly online quizzes on the course website that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. There are 8 quizzes in total based on Units 1,2,3,5,6,7,9 and 10 and they are due in Weeks 2 to 11.

Each quiz will consist of 5 questions. Most questions are multiple-choice style but there are also a few calculation questions. You will have 1 hour to complete each quiz from the time you first open it. Your final grade will be based on your best 6 quiz scores. For more detailed information about this assessment including the start and finish times for each quiz, please refer to the 'Quiz Instructions' document under the 'Quizzes' section of the course website.

More detail on each case study and the questions that must be answered will be available in the 'Case Study Instructions' document under the 'Case Studies' section of the course website.

The final assessment is an online exam that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. It will be performed on Moodle course site and will involve a mix of multiple choice style questions, multi-part problem style questions and also some short-essay questions. The questions will be based on Units 1 to 10 of the course. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Exam Instructions' document under the 'Exam' section in Moodle.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9138","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9138 - Financial Analysis","description":"

The practical aim of this course is to present the tools necessary to undertake business analysis using financial statement information, and to show how these tools can be applied to a wide range of decision-making contexts. We aim to provide you with up-to-date applied knowledge of fundamental valuation techniques, pitfalls of accounting reports, and "reading between the lines" of financial reports.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ebc7ed3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961905","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project (Case Study)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment 2 is a group project (case study) that requires students to work in groups of five (5) to conduct a complete analysis and valuation of a publicly listed company, and to submit a written report and digital presentation at the end of Week 8.

Specifically, the group project requires students to conduct a complete analysis and valuation of a listed company.

Weekly group project activities are embedded throughout the the online course website, up until submission in Week 8. 

The team should plan how it will undertake the work for the group project. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"13c7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"17c7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1fc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"2bc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5fc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"63c7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9bc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"afc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d7c7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"ebc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0fc7ad3bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Take-home Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will complete a take-home assessment task that will consist of questions designed to assess your comprehension of the material we will cover in the course. They will be based around a current, real company’s financial statements.

Assessment 1 comprises two online open-book tests. These will comprise a combination of multiple-choice, true/false and matching-pairs questions, as well as some numerical and financial calculations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9139 - Entrepreneurial Finance","description":"

This course seeks to understand what venture capital is, what venture capitalists do and the way venture capital organisations work. This course is primarily geared towards students interested in working in venture capital, or other private-equity organizations. It is also intended for students who expect to work alongside venture capitalists or other private equity investors, whether as managers of firms financed by such investors, as investment bankers taking their firms public, or as money managers investing in these funds. Finally, it is designed for students interested in exploring how aspects of private equity investing can be transferred to the management of projects in established organizations.

The objective of the final assignment is to test whether you have achieved the learning objectives of Units 1 to 10 of the course.  Answers should include using the models, theories and methodologies that are taught in the units that are being assessed. Broad answers not only on common-sense or your own experiences. Where appropriate,  answers should briefly explore multiple points of view and identify any flaws in your own analysis.

contentlets.keywords: mbax,mergers and acquisitions,corporate finance,global finance,financial analysis,entrepreneurial finance
contentlets.description: This course seeks to understand what venture capital is, what venture capitalists do and the way venture capital organisations work. This course is primarily geared towards students interested in working in venture capital, or other private-equity organizations. It is also intended for students who expect to work alongside venture capitalists or other private equity investors, whether as managers of firms financed by such investors, as investment bankers taking their firms public, or as money managers investing in these funds. Finally, it is designed for students interested in exploring how aspects of private equity investing can be transferred to the management of projects in established organizations.
contentlets.title: Entrepreneurial Finance

This course is a joint activity between the Institute of Global Finance at the UNSW Business School and the Volatility Insitute at Stern Business School, NYU. The course will provide information and analysis on the latest developments in the world of finance and their implications for business strategies. The course will use articles from The Wall Street Journal and The Financial Times to complement a number of issues that influence global finance and the way multinational companies build their global business networks, their activities and strategies. The latest issues on global finance will be taught in this course, with online lectures, videos and other online materials. 


The basic thrust of this course is to provide a framework within which the key global financial issues, including financial risk and the operations of multinational companies, can be analysed. This course is designed to develop students' understanding of the business and financial aspects of their main specialisation.


The course prepares students for leadership roles and builds understanding of global financial forces that could influence the overall business environment. There will be some videos of experts from KPMG, eminent scholars in finance from the US who will share their insights on aspects of global finance.

Each group of three to four students will be given a multinational company to study. The focus of the group project is on evaluation students' understanding of a way they study one large multinational company's operation with a focus on these following 4 core aspects:

\n\n
  1. Business strategies
  2. Financial risk management
  3. Social and cultural awareness of the business situation in its overall operations
  4. Ethical transparency, social and/or environmental responsibility in is decision-making process
\n\n

A more detailed outline of the exact requirements of the Group Project will be communicated in week 1.

The final examination focuses on evaluating student's understanding of the main concepts covered in this course. The final exam covers all the topics that are covered in this course. Students are encouraged to study the textbook and the PPTs provided for this course.

contentlets.description:
This course is a joint activity between the Institute of Global Finance at the UNSW Business School and the Volatility Insitute at Stern Business School, NYU. The course will provide information and analysis on the latest developments in the world of finance and their implications for business strategies. The course will use articles from The Wall Street Journal and The Financial Times to complement a number of issues that influence global finance and the way multinational companies build their global business networks, their activities and strategies. The latest issues on global finance will be taught in this course, with online lectures, videos and other online materials. 

The basic thrust of this course is to provide a framework within which the key global financial issues, including financial risk and the operations of multinational companies, can be analysed. This course is designed to develop students' understanding of the business and financial aspects of their main specialisation.

The course prepares students for leadership roles and builds understanding of global financial forces that could influence the overall business environment. There will be some videos of experts from KPMG, eminent scholars in finance from the US who will share their insights on aspects of global finance.
contentlets.title: Global Finance

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9141","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9141 - Mergers and Acquisitions","description":"

The objective of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to successfully initiate, analyse, evaluate and implement M&A transactions. The course will explore the development and execution of transactions including business acquisitions, takeovers, divestments, and initial public offerings. In addition, students will consider corporate and business strategies that motivate M&A transactions and the motivations of financial buyers such as private equity participants in M&A markets. Students will learn to assess targets and value target businesses by applying corporate finance tools and knowledge within the context of evaluating, developing and executing M&A transactions. The course emphasises the practical applications of skills and knowledge through a combination of case studies, group activities and online discussions.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"14067755db035050358b403c3a961994","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Individual growth strategy and M&A valuation paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is an individual development of a strategy involving identification and justification of an M&A target and valuation of the M&A target from the position of the chosen case study business. This work is presented in the form of a management working paper.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"024abf19db035050358b403c3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"15aa7759db035050358b403c3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"266abf19db035050358b403c3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c06b755db035050358b403c3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"b99a3759db035050358b403c3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"e8ea3759db035050358b403c3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f40abf19db035050358b403c3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fb1abf19db035050358b403c3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4506f755db035050358b403c3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 Task A: Development of an M&A proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment builds directly on the individual team members' work on Assessment 2. The team can share and review the insights provided by Assessment 2 as a form of past research, but the proposal developed for this Assessment is an extension of the ground work provided by Assessment 2. Importantly, the team now works together as corporate advisors or consultants to the chosen business to develop a unique, cohesive and comprehensive strategy for M&A value creation for the focus organisation. In this assessment the team will develop and present a comprehensive proposal for value creation through M&A plus supporting material. The proposal is to include a single or multiple M&A transactions and may also include divestments. Importantly the M&A proposal should present a convincing argument and feasible plan for the management of the organisation to pursue the M&A proposal and address important points for the management to consider in making a decision to pursue the proposed strategy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"024abf19db035050358b403c3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"15aa7759db035050358b403c3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"266abf19db035050358b403c3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9006b755db035050358b403c3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c06b755db035050358b403c3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"b99a3759db035050358b403c3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"e8ea3759db035050358b403c3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"f1cab759db035050358b403c3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f40abf19db035050358b403c3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fb1abf19db035050358b403c3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5106f755db035050358b403c3a961909","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Ongoing throughout the term

The purpose of online class participation is to help you develop your ideas through active interaction and engagement with your peers and the facilitator. You should incorporate concepts, models, frameworks and theories from the course when expressing your ideas, and use appropriate analysis and justification when expressing coherent concise points of view. You should also expand on, and drive, the conversation by meaningfully responding to contributions from other students.

Three types of student contributions are possible during the flow of discussions with fellow classmates. These are:

  • Original posts created in response to the posed weekly activity or question
  • Response posts where you address the replies other students have made to your original post.
  • Reply posts made to other students’

Original Posts that you make should be up to 250 words. Responses and replies should be up to approximately half this length. The goal is to be concise and to avoid writing essays in a discussion.

Note that your facilitator may set specific activities and interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

Feedback

You will receive feedback on your level of participation at the mid-point of the course and a final mark at the end of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"15aa7759db035050358b403c3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"266abf19db035050358b403c3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9006b755db035050358b403c3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c06b755db035050358b403c3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"b99a3759db035050358b403c3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"e8ea3759db035050358b403c3a9619ad","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6c06b755db035050358b403c3a9619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 Task B: Peer evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"0","description":"

Each student has the option to evaluate the contribution made by each member of their team for Assessment 3. Evaluations will be confidential – that is, your teammates will not know what marks you have awarded to them or see the comments you make.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"f1cab759db035050358b403c3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76a6cc21db435050358b403c3a96197e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 Task C: Critique of M&A proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

In this third component of Assessment 3, multiple student peers in the cohort — the exact number will depend on the number of enrolments and the number of teams — will independently respond to a team’s M&A proposal and determine the three most important questions to ask the team of “advisors” who put forward the proposal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"f1cab759db035050358b403c3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b527cc61db435050358b403c3a9619f4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The first assessment is composed of five small quizzes that act as an active, formative learning tool to promote better recall and deeper learning.

Quiz 1A Due: Week 2 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1B Due: Week 4 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1C Due: Week 6 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1D Due: Week 8 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1E Due: Week 10 Weighting: 3%

contentlets.keywords: mbax,mergers and acquisitions,corporate finance,global finance,financial analysis,entrepreneurial finance
contentlets.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to successfully initiate, analyse, evaluate and implement M&A transactions. The course will explore the development and execution of transactions including business acquisitions, takeovers, divestments, and initial public offerings. In addition, students will consider corporate and business strategies that motivate M&A transactions and the motivations of financial buyers such as private equity participants in M&A markets. Students will learn to assess targets and value target businesses by applying corporate finance tools and knowledge within the context of evaluating, developing and executing M&A transactions. The course emphasises the practical applications of skills and knowledge through a combination of case studies, group activities and online discussions.
contentlets.title: Mergers and Acquisitions

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9142","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9142 - Financial Modelling","description":"

Financial Modelling intends to make managers more confident and effective users of financial models, helping them to better understand and communicate the practical value of financial models, and to build this literacy for their future work. Key to this is a critical pedagogical approach which develops and refines students’ high-level critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills, alongside providing them with a set of practical tools and techniques to help them make effective judgments about a business’s current financial situation and future performance based on best practice financial modelling principles.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"31b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Capstone modelling task","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment will require you to build a financial model from scratch for a fictitious social media company called Fakebook. Your financial model will need to forecast the three financial statements in an integrated manner, based on a set of background information that will be provided. You will then use your model to answer a series of quiz questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"22b2620bdb875450358b403c3a9619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2A: Pizza Planet amendment #1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

In this task, you will take the case study model that we have been developing together and amend it to reflect a new public holiday. You will use your updated model to answer a series of questions. This task is aimed at giving you an opportunity to experience what it is like to amend an existing model (and all the dangers that entails).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ab2620bdb875450358b403c3a9619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1B : Modelling critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This task follows on from the introductory modelling task, and it will give you an opportunity to further reflect on your attempt, this time with reference to the best practice principles that you will learn throughout the course. We hope that in genuinely undertaking this reflection, you will be able to gauge how far you have come on your learning journey.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8eb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1A : Introductory modelling task","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

In this task, you will be required to construct a financial model to assist with deciding whether it is better to buy the home you live in, or rent and invest in an index fund. The purpose of this task is to give you an opportunity to experience how difficult it can be to build a robust financial model without a solid foundation of best practices to lean on. Given this task is assigned at the start of the course (before we have taught you anything), you will not be assessed on the quality of your output, but rather the quality of a reflection that you will prepare, outlining your approach and struggles.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"96b2620bdb875450358b403c3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2B: Pizza Planet amendment #2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

In this task, you will once again update your case study model, this time to change the way in which tax losses operate. We chose this task specifically because it is one of the most complex challenges that financial modellers face in their roles. If you are able to successfully complete this task, you can have the confidence to tackle any challenge that the world of financial modelling throws at you.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Final Online Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment will last 90 minutes and contains 20 questions, each worth 1 mark. These questions will comprise:

  • 6 questions that test your Excel knowledge
  • 5 questions that test your financial modelling knowledge
  • 3 questions that test your ability to solve complex logic problems using Excel
  • 6 questions that test your ability to develop a financial model

The 6 questions that test your ability to develop a financial model will involve you downloading some background information and an Excel file containing a partially completed model. You will be required to complete the missing logic in that model, and then use the results of your formulas to answer the 6 questions. You will also be required to upload your completed model as part of the assessment.

The questions will be a combination of multiple choice, true/false and numerical answers. All topics covered throughout the course can be tested, and we would advise that as part of your preparation, you should:

  • Watch all videos in their entirety at least once.
  • Complete the Pizza Planet case study and correctly answer all the status check questions.
  • Revise each of the stand-alone Excel activities that were introduced throughout the course.
  • Complete the practice questions provided in the sample test which will be made available to you. This sample test provides a good indication of the style of questions that you will encounter.

The assessment will be open book and you can reference any of the course materials that you think may help you. Naturally, you will need to sit the assessment on a computer that has Microsoft Excel installed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5b2620bdb875450358b403c3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb2620bdb875450358b403c3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dab2620bdb875450358b403c3a961958","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MBAX9142.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9143","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9143 - Strategic Management","description":"

Strategic Management is designed to help you to apply knowledge in understanding how the managers of modern, technology-rich, sustainable organisations look to generate, communicate and fulfil a strategic vision and deliver outcomes that fulfil the purpose for which the organisations were created.


Whether you work in small business or major international organisations, in the public sector, private industry or not-for-profit sector, strategic management plays a central role in understanding and defining answers to four fundamental questions.


  • Where are we now?
  • Where do we want or need to go?
  • How will we get there?
  • How will we make sure we stay on track to get there?

  • Participate and contribute effectively to a multi-functional team to deliver a  shared outcome to a high standard
  • Analyse and evaluate the team processes and your own contribution to the  effective outcome of the team
  • Participate and contribute effectively to a multi-functional team to deliver a shared outcome to a high standard
  • Identify social and cultural aspects or dimensions and their influence on an organisation's strategic situation and the implications for strategic management practice.
  • Outline techniques for identifying and acknowledging the key stakeholders to the organisation's strategy and a means to communicate strategy effectively to these stakeholders
  • Develop a strategic plan and identify the key actions and processes to implement and manage an appropriate strategic option
  • Develop and evaluate a range of appropriate strategic options based on an understanding of the organisation's strategic position
  • Analyse forces in an organisation's internal and external strategic environment and draw strategically significant conclusions based on these
  • Undertake primary and secondary research to gather information relevant to making strategic decisions
  • Identify, critically analysis and develop responses to strategic management challenged faced by an organisation using relevant theory
  • Apply key strategic management concepts, models, frameworks and tools to assess and recommend improvement to the strategic and technology management practices of local and/or global organisations
  • Identify key current disciplinary or interdisciplinary knowledge regarding the value proposition of applying technology to local and/or global  business situations

contentlets.description:
Strategic Management is designed to help you to apply knowledge in understanding how the managers of modern, technology-rich, sustainable organisations look to generate, communicate and fulfil a strategic vision and deliver outcomes that fulfil the purpose for which the organisations were created.

Whether you work in small business or major international organisations, in the public sector, private industry or not-for-profit sector, strategic management plays a central role in understanding and defining answers to four fundamental questions.

  • Where are we now?
  • Where do we want or need to go?
  • How will we get there?
  • How will we make sure we stay on track to get there?
contentlets.title: Strategic Management

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9150","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9150 - Digital Innovation","description":"

Innovation and the management of technology are critical in driving economic productivity and improving the future wellbeing of society. Advances in the accessibility of modern technology, and increasingly connected social and alternative financing methods have decreased barriers in the practice of entrepreneurship, enabling digital innovation to flourish. As a result, digital innovation is empowering many people, from digital natives to those living in developing countries, to create solutions and drive change. In addition, the speed at which entrepreneurs can disrupt established business practices is causing more organisations to adopt agile and entrepreneurial methods for developing and managing new technology, products and services.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"120b8abcdb0b1c10358b403c3a96195b","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Participation and engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Active participation, engagement, and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

You will receive feedback on your participation at the end of Week 4 and a final mark at the end of the course.

In Weeks 1 to 10 there will be an online quiz testing your knowledge of the core curriculum readings. Each quiz will consist of four true/false or multiple-choice questions. You will have eight minutes to complete each quiz and cannot revisit a question once the answer for that question has been submitted.

Out of the 10 quizzes, your best eight results will be used to determine your mark for this assessment.

This assessment is an opportunity for students to identify a digital innovation either in their own work place or elsewhere and make a presentation on its virtues. Students will, in groups, create a venture plan either for an internal corporate venture, or for a startup venture.

The assessment can include, but is not restricted to, the following elements:

1. Digital innovation of interest and background

2. Rationale for selection or motivation with level of maturity of the digital innovation, can be early conceptual or mature

3. Benefit to society / business, etc.

4. Use case by client with key features

5. Examples of implementation if any in society or organisations

6. Financial viability of the digital innovation, with capital needs

7. Improvements into the future of current technical characteristics

8. Recommendation of the digital innovation in terms of uses / business value / customer segments.

9. Adequate referencing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d20bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d20bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a96198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"d20bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a96198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d20bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"da0bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"da0bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"de0bcabcdb0b1c10358b403c3a961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"981b0ebcdb0b1c10358b403c3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Conference proceedings on an emerging technology","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will develop a conference proceeding in the form of a presentation. Your boss, the Chief Technology Officer, has been asked to present to an international conference (student to select) on an emerging technology or innovation they are exploring and are promoting the potential use, implementation and commercialisation opportunity. This could include what has been done recently and their experiences so far. The problem is, the CTO has been asked to attend an executive off-site, and you have the chance to pull this together and promote your organisation.

Students will look at an emerging digital innovation that may impact society and/ or businesses but is yet to be commercialised. Students will explore various Gartner Hype Cycles to be able to identify a suitable emerging innovation. Aspects to explore could be, but are not limited to, the following:

  1. A clear definition of the innovation
  2. The maturity level, i.e. is it still in the research phase, prototype or is it ready for trials/testing
  3. The overall value to industry and organisation
  4. Potential benefits to the customer base. Identify which customer base you intend to serve
  5. How would the solution/s be implemented?
  6. What could be the risks?
  7. What financial benefit / value could be derived from a potential solution/s?
  8. What time frame would you envisage for a ROI?

Hint: the blockchain / bitcoin, driverless cars, biometrics have had a similar journey.

Students will then present the potential opportunities should this innovation be commercialised.

Each student may optionally evaluate the contribution made by each member of their team for this assessment. This evaluation is scored out of 10.

This process allows students to more clearly indicate the apportioning of workload within the team that actually occurred. The task is optional as it may not be necessary to do this if the team performed well in its tasks.

Evaluations will be confidential – that is, your team mates will not know what rating you have awarded to them or see the comments you make.

Active participation, engagement, and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

You will receive feedback on your participation at the end of Week 4 and a final mark at the end of the course.

contentlets.description: Innovation and the management of technology are critical in driving economic productivity and improving the future wellbeing of society. Advances in the accessibility of modern technology, and increasingly connected social and alternative financing methods have decreased barriers in the practice of entrepreneurship, enabling digital innovation to flourish. As a result, digital innovation is empowering many people, from digital natives to those living in developing countries, to create solutions and drive change. In addition, the speed at which entrepreneurs can disrupt established business practices is causing more organisations to adopt agile and entrepreneurial methods for developing and managing new technology, products and services.
contentlets.title: Digital Innovation

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9151","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9151 - Law, Regulation & Ethics","description":"

Organisations and the individuals who work in them need to ensure that they operate lawfully and in a manner that meets stakeholder expectations and broader community standards of acceptable behaviour. This is true across business entities, not-for-profits and in the business of government. It requires managers to understand and be accountable for compliance with a complex array of legal and non-legal rules and expectations, derived from different sources. The reputational risk which flows from decisions influenced by personal, professional and institutional ethics can be amplified enormously by social media. This course is designed to equip students with the analytical tools to identify and manage the governance, compliance and risk management issues that arise from law, regulation and ethics in the context of businesses’ relationship with society. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"62344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619ef","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Video Presentation and Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are expected to present in a group on a case.

In Week 1, the facilitator will upload a video explaining the background, context and events of Case 1 (Rana Plaza).

For subsequent weeks, students will work in teams to prepare and upload/share a similar presentation on the case to which they are assigned (which will then be used for that week's discussion activity).

This will be in the format of video added to an Outlook 365 PowerPoint file.

This must be uploaded to Moodle on Sunday evening by 5pm - that is, one day prior to the week in which the case is to be discussed. This ensures the discussion can start promptly and without delay.

In addition to the video, each team needs to produce a short (2 page) summary of their presentation/case overview. Because these case studies have complex facts the summary is a useful aid for your colleagues to ensure they have the basic facts and details about the case. It may also help you in preparing your script for the presentation (in fact it may be an edited version of the script). The summary should be uploaded at the same time as the video.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2a344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2e344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2e344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b348707db0b5450358b403c3a961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3B: Case Analysis - Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The Final Report is a research essay that uses the Case you have selected to draw out and explore issues of law, regulation and ethics. Each Case involves a sector, entity or individual engaging in conduct that caused or may cause harm, and demonstrates the challenges faced by society in setting and enforcing normative standards for business and by business in achieving meaningful compliance. How would a well-governed, sustainable and responsible entity manage those risks?

Your Final Report should identify and engage with those challenges, and explore conceptual and practical ways of addressing them.

In Weeks 2 to 10 there will be prompts for online discussion by the whole class. Each student is expected to contribute to that discussion. The discussion for each week will be on a forum on Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"26344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2a344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2e344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2e344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa344707db0b5450358b403c3a9619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3A: Case Analysis - Outline and Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 3 requires you to analyse and reflect on one of the Cases discussed during the course. Each Case we study raises a range of issues that are not limited to the specific Unit in which it was discussed.

This assessment task gives you the chance to reflect more broadly on the issues of law, regulation and ethics faced by the industry, entity or individuals involved in the selected Case.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MBAX9152","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MBAX9152 - Digital Strategy","description":"

This course focuses on the key concepts, practices and issues in the strategic management of digital technologies. The course covers two key themes. First, the course begins with examining the strategic role and organisational value of digital technologies, including digitally-enabled innovation, digital ecosystems, and digital transformation and disruption. Second, the course examines the strategic management of digital technologies required to realise this value potential, including current and emerging approaches and frameworks for strategic decision-making about digital technologies, and the management of digital service delivery.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4326328bdbc75450358b403c3a96190d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3A: Develop a Digital Strategy","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Your team report should include and address the items below, in the order in which they are presented.

Task 1: Industry analysis
(20% of assignment marks)

Analyse the competitive forces affecting the industry in which your organisation operates. What are the key drivers of competitive advantage in this industry? How, if at all, are these drivers changing?

Task 2: Business strategy analysis
(20% of assignment marks)

Review and summarise your organisation’s business strategy and business practices. How does your organisation aim to differentiate itself from its key competitors? Discuss how much emphasis your organisation currently places on digital technologies in its business strategy.

Task 3: Digital trends
(20% of assignment marks)

Identify and discuss the opportunities and threats that increasing digitisation poses for your organisation. You may want to refer to your work in Unit 3 to help you work through this task. Discuss the impact of each of the trends you identify, considering your organisation’s strategy and competitive environment.

Task 4: Recommendations
(30% of assignment marks)

Recommend three key emerging technologies that your organisation should invest in to gain competitive advantage and/or to remain competitive. Using specific examples, discuss how your organisation should use each of these technologies for strategic value. Discuss how your organisation may need to change its business strategy or practices to successfully leverage these technologies.

Presentation style/effectiveness
(10% of assignment marks)

The presentation will be evaluated on its logical and coherent structure; the smooth flow of ideas; the effectiveness of the delivery and communication, and appearance of visual aids, including appropriate use of tables and diagrams. For referencing, please use the Harvard Referencing style (https://student.unsw.edu.au/harvard-referencing).

Each student may optionally evaluate the contribution made by each member of their team for this assessment. This evaluation is scored out of 10.

This process allows students to more clearly indicate the apportioning of workload within the team that actually occurred. The task is optional as it may not be necessary to do this if the team performed well in its tasks.

Evaluations will be confidential – that is, your team mates will not know what rating you have awarded to them or see the comments you make.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"e8b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2B: Commentary on your best 5 blogs","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

In Part B you will choose the 5 blogs that you connected with the most and format them into one coherent submission. You will have an additional 500 words which you can use for an introduction, conclusion or to add to the blogs. You are allowed to rewrite your blogs before final submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e0b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ecb53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a9619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2A: Weekly blogs","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

In Weeks 2 through 9, write one blog per week (a total of eight blogs). The blog post activity is described in the unit materials where you are asked to reflect on and respond to a set of questions focused on the weekly theme. You will use a blogging platform to author your weekly posts. More details will be made available in Moodle about this activity and use of the blogging tool.

Each blog should be related to a central theme. The blog posts should be based on a company which is not the same as the one used in the group project.

Please ensure you research your response and include references where relevant.

Your blog must be an individual effort. Each blog post should be no more than 300 words in length. References are excluded from this word count.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e8b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1b53e4bdbc75450358b403c3a9619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation through Class Discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Active participation and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way, we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative. Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

Please ensure after making your initial post that you respond to at least 2 of your class mates.

Note that to improve the class discussions we will be breaking up large classes into smaller discussion groups. These groups will be assigned automatically and are likely to have about 10 members per group.

You will receive feedback on your participation at the end of Week 5 and a final mark at the end of the course.

In the content for each Unit, there is one designated class discussion activity focused on discussing a specific set of questions with your teammates. Every team will have a Moodle forum thread set up to serve as a platform for discussing the team activity. In your forum thread, you should seek to both contribute new, independent insights as well as to respond and build on the ideas of others.

Implementing Strategy","description":"

This course provides students with applied, critical thinking and application skills for effective strategy implementation. With a focus on a spectrum of principles and features that influence strategy execution, it helps develop practical insights into organisational transformation. The course aligns with the content of other strategy courses, but focuses on the spectrum of issues to translate strategy implementation detailing how organisations can achieve sustained effectiveness with both its current challenges and future possibilities. In this context, the course deals with themes on the strategic process of managing for change, redesigning structure, human capital and talent management, and smart responses to technology. The course challenges students to think critically and develop useful insights about the concepts and principles on making better strategy. 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"14583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cb","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Oral Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

In this assessment you are required to produce a short video reflection. Given the many variants available to developing and implementing strategy, the choices and challenges available to strategists are diverse. In this course we have attempted to give shape to some of the issues and dimensions available in crafting and executing strategy, guided by insights into the planning, thinking, critical insights, and mindsets that accompanying effective strategy. That is, highlighting that strategy implementation is both a set plan and a shape-shifting exercise, guided by strategist choice. 

In this final assessment, you now turn to reflecting on the strategic conversations that you have had over the term and with your colleagues. Built around content, the exercise is meant to enable you to identify key takeaways that were meaningful to you and to deconstruct or understand them based on what you learned. This is a different format to extend ideas and show your understanding. It is personal application, meant to encourage deep thinking and insightful analysis.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"50583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"58583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"10583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Individual Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In this course, we assume that the formulation and implementation of strategy are intertwined as complex, interactive processes in which politics, values, organisational culture, and management styles determine or constrain particular strategic decisions. In exploring this theme we consider two different schools of thought on how to approach strategy – planned strategy and strategic thinking. With this divergence we recognise (Unit 2) that strategy can be an open system that interrelates strategy elements as they evolve, or a comprehensive management model that links strategy and operations, considering effective strategy development, planning, and management tools to achieve sustainable strategic success. 

At the heart of this discussion is a fundamental difference on what effective strategy implementation looks like, that: (1) a formal, planned strategy is essential to enable strategic success, or (2) formal planning is not the best way to develop strategy because strategy needs intuition and crafting. 

Recognising this distinction, for this assessment use either a crafting strategy (Mintzberg, unit 1) or a strategic planning (Kaplan and Norton, unit 2) frame to critically evaluate your organisation’s current primary strategy and its implementation (or alternatively, if not possible for an organisation you have recently worked for). 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"50583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"50583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Interactive participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"13","description":"

You are expected to participate and contribute to discussion (in online dialogues for the online mode, and in class dialogue interactions in the intensive mode)

Online Dialogue: Within each online dialogue activity, each student is required to make postings at least twice in the week to allow reasonable dialogue with other students. The maximum word count of each posting is 200 words. For these Units, there is an explicit dialogue activity that each student needs to prepare to discuss in class. Each student should expect to contribute to team and whole class discussions.

Dialogues take place in Weeks 1, 2, 6 and 8

Weighting: Each participation week is worth 2% for a total of 8%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"50583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"58583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"58583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"58583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"25587b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a96191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Group Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

For this report, in your team, carry out a critical analysis and assessment of a failed or poor strategy implementation. Select a case and organisation that has undergone strategy change or transformation to evaluate the lessons learned and to extend application from the implementation. Historical examples include Polaroid’s digital camera; the online pet supply retailing, and Dick Smith, while prominent recent examples include Tata Nano, Toys R Us and the NBN. The focus is not on bankruptcy or terminal failure but on strategy implementation that led to failures and poor outcomes. It is your responsibility to find and select the case and organisation and to prepare the report. Before commencing your report, you will need to confirm your organisation selection with your class facilitator. The key to your selection is to narrow your focus rather than attempt to undertake a full industry and strategy assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"50583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"50583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"58583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"58583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c583b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59587b54dbf75450eb6b147a3a961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Team-based Activity","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"12","description":"

Three times during the course you are expected to complete short activities directly related to Unit content. These activities need to be completed in your study team (formed in Week 1). These activities vary in what they require you to do but are applications on content that teams need to present, defend, or promote. They do not require extra reading or preparation but are a means for you to extend Unit content and your understanding of it in a fun and interactive way. Each activity is meant to encourage critical thinking, presentation development, and problem-solving skills by directly applying course content. These activities take place in weeks when you do not have other assessments. Instructions for each activity is given in the units in which they appear.

Unit 3: Present a 1-page slide response (“How does a firm know if its organizational design is appropriate for its strategy?”) – 3%

Unit 5: Debate your peers to make your case (“Strategic agility is a waste of productive time. After all, sustained strategy implementation in VUCA really needs clear direction and consistent leadership.”) – 4%

Unit 7: Make a soapbox presentation to speak up about a statement on human capital (aligning human capital with strategy) - 5%

Weighting: 12% total

The maximum word count of each posting is 200 words. For these Units, there is an explicit dialogue activity that each student needs to prepare to discuss in class. Each student should expect to contribute to team and whole class discussions.

Dialogues take place in Weeks 1, 2, 6 and 8

Weighting: Each participation week is worth 2% for a total of 8%

For this report, in your team, carry out a critical analysis and assessment of a failed or poor strategy implementation. Select a case and organisation that has undergone strategy change or transformation to evaluate the lessons learned and to extend application from the implementation. Historical examples include Polaroid’s digital camera; the online pet supply retailing, and Dick Smith, while prominent recent examples include Tata Nano, Toys R Us and the NBN. The focus is not on bankruptcy or terminal failure but on strategy implementation that led to failures and poor outcomes. It is your responsibility to find and select the case and organisation and to prepare the report. Before commencing your report, you will need to confirm your organisation selection with your class facilitator. The key to your selection is to narrow your focus rather than attempt to undertake a full industry and strategy assessment.
